title: Dynamics of Gender Bias within Computer Science
abstract:
A new dataset (N = 7,456) analyzes women's research authorship in the
Association for Computing Machinery's founding 13 Special Interest Groups or
SIGs, a proxy for computer science. ACM SIGs expanded during 1970-2000; each
experienced increasing women's authorship. But diversity abounds. Several SIGs
had fewer than 10% women authors while SIGUCCS (university computing centers)
exceeded 40%. Three SIGs experienced accelerating growth in women's authorship;
most, including a composite ACM, had decelerating growth. This research may
encourage reform efforts, often focusing on general education or workforce
factors (across the entity of "computer science"), to examine under-studied
dynamics within computer science that shaped changes in women's participation.
